questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician for recurrent episodes of shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and chest tightness for 3 months. These episodes occur especially while playing sports and resolve spontaneously with rest. She appears healthy. Her pulse is 63/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 102/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows a FEV1:FVC ratio of 85% and an FEV1 of 85% of predicted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest could reveal a pulmonary disease underlying this patient's respiratory symptoms. However, in this patient with symptoms suggestive of exercise-induced asthma, CT would be unlikely to reveal an underlying condition. In addition, the substantial amount of radiation should especially be avoided in this teenage girl.

B) CORRECT:

Exercise-induced asthma presents with symptoms of bronchoconstriction (e.g., shortness of breath, chest tightness) that typically peaks 10–15 minutes after beginning exercise. Exercise-induced asthma is treated with short-acting β2-agonists (e.g., albuterol) taken shortly (5–20 minutes) before exercise. Due to the risk of tachyphylaxis, β2-agonists should preferentially only be used before the most strenuous exercise sessions. Additional treatment options include avoiding exercise in cold weather (or using a mask to warm inhaled air) and avoiding triggers (allergic or environmental).

C) INCORRECT:

Prednisone therapy would not be the first-line therapy in exercise-induced asthma in a patient who has not tried other methods. Prednisone would generally be indicated if the patient had severe underlying asthma with an acute exacerbation that is not relieved by inhaled bronchodilators.

D) INCORRECT:

Although improved physical conditioning can improve minute ventilation and help improve the symptoms of exercise-induced asthma, this patient should initially be offered alternative management to help with her underlying disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography can be useful in young patients who present with symptoms suggestive of congestive heart failure (peripheral edema, crackles), hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (systolic murmur), or other valvular abnormalities. Cardiac involvement is unlikely in this patient whose physical examination showed no abnormalities and who has no symptoms at rest.
questions.hint: This adolescent girl has features of bronchoconstriction such as shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and chest tightness only while playing sports. Her spirometry findings are normal. These findings suggest exercise-induced asthma.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent episodes of shortness of breath, chest tightness, and nonproductive cough that first started about 4 months ago. He says these episodes usually occur during or shortly after soccer practice and resolve spontaneously when he stops exercising. He has no shortness of breath at other times, including at night. His sister has allergic rhinitis. His pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows a FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.88 and an FEV1 of 91% of predicted. Bronchodilator responsiveness testing is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skin prick testing can be used to identify allergens that trigger allergic asthma. This patient, however, has no history of allergic conditions (e.g., atopy), and his clinical presentation (i.e., symptoms provoked during or after exercise) suggests exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.

B) INCORRECT:

Single-breath diffusing capacity (DLCO) is usually performed to differentiate between intrapulmonary and extrapulmonary causes of restrictive lung disease or hypoxemia that remain unexplained even after spirometry. Since this patient has normal spirometry findings and no hypoxemia, another test should be performed to diagnose his condition.

C) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray can be useful in severe cases of asthma to evaluate for signs of lung hyperinflation (e.g., flattened diaphragmatic contours, hyperlucent lungs) or to rule out alternative diagnoses, such as pneumothorax or pneumonia. This patient's clinical presentation suggests exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, in which chest x-ray findings would be normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Eosinophils and total IgE concentration may be elevated in patients with atopy, certain infections, and allergic asthma. This patient has no history of allergies or infection, and total IgE concentration and eosinophil count are neither sensitive nor specific for such conditions. Moreover, this patient's clinical presentation (i.e., symptoms provoked during or after exercise) suggests exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's spirometry findings show only mild reductions in FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio, and bronchodilator responsiveness testing is negative. However, this patient presents with features of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, making another step in diagnosis more appropriate.

F) CORRECT:

Exercise is a trigger of bronchoconstriction, which typically occurs in individuals with underlying asthma. A methacholine challenge test is a type of bronchial provocation test used to diagnose exercise-induced bronchoconstriction in patients with inconclusive spirometry findings. Although a methacholine challenge test is effective for determining both the hyperresponsiveness of airways and the reversibility of the obstruction, it should be carried out carefully because of its inherent but minimal risk of inducing a life-threatening asthma attack.

An exercise challenge test is the method of choice for the definitive diagnosis of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.
questions.hint: This patient has shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, chest tightness while exercising, and normal spirometry findings, all of which suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman reports a 3-year history of increasingly severe and frequent episodes of wheezing and dyspnea. She has been hospitalized four times during this period and was treated with prednisone and albuterol for presumed asthma. Her last admission was 2 weeks ago. As an outpatient, she has been treated with inhaled salmeterol and fluticasone. She is asymptomatic between episodes.
She has never smoked and does not have any allergy symptoms. She had no asthma as a child. She has a history of hypertension and anxiety.
Her vital signs are normal, and her lungs are clear on auscultation. Cardiac examination is normal. She has no peripheral edema or skin changes.
Chest radiography shows no opacities.
Full pulmonary function testing yields normal results. Methacholine challenge does not reveal airway hyperresponsiveness.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of the serum immunoglobulin E level

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vocal-cord dysfunction should be suspected in a patient who experiences shortness of breath, coughing, and tightness of the chest for brief periods despite adequate treatment for asthma. During these episodes, the patient typically has normal oxygen saturation and appears acutely dyspneic. Auscultation of the chest may reveal more prominent wheezing over the proximal airways and sometimes stridor.

Normally, vocal cords are open during inhalation. Vocal-cord dysfunction or paradoxical vocal-fold motion can be diagnosed when the vocal cords are observed to close abnormally during inhalation. Laboratory tests are usually unrevealing between episodes, and the patient’s symptoms may be erroneously attributed to anxiety.

Allergic reactions, asthma, obstruction of the vocal cords, and neurologic causes may manifest similarly, and symptoms may occur suddenly or gradually. This disorder has been observed throughout the life span, and a physiologic cause (such as reflux- or allergy-causing vocal-cord swelling and consequent abnormal motion) is likely. Although many patients may also have a history of asthma, patients often report a difference between a difficulty exhaling, common in asthma, and a difficulty inhaling, characteristic of vocal-cord dysfunction.

Direct visualization of the vocal cords, such as by means of laryngoscopy, is usually required to diagnose vocal-cord dysfunction, with visualization of abnormal adduction confirming the diagnosis. Occasionally, if a patient is having an acute symptomatic episode, flow-volume loops reveal a plateau in inspiratory airflow consistent with a variable extrathoracic obstruction. However, in the absence of an acute episode, flow-volume loops will be normal.

Key learning point: The best method to diagnose vocal-cord dysfunction is laryngoscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Although some patients do have vocal-cord dysfunction in association with exercise, provocation of wheezing with the use of exercise on a treadmill would not distinguish between vocal-cord dysfunction and exercise-induced asthma. Postexercise spirometry could be of value if the patient had vocal-cord dysfunction with exercise.

C) INCORRECT:

CT of the neck would not show the vocal cords at good resolution and would not reveal atypical movement, although it could reveal a large goiter or mass that is compressing the extrathoracic trachea. Compression or obstruction of the large airways should be shown on a flow-volume curve.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum immunoglobulin E levels are often elevated in patients with asthma or other atopic diseases but are not useful in diagnosing vocal-cord dysfunction. This patient’s history and testing, most notably the normal results on methacholine challenge, are not consistent with asthma.

E) INCORRECT:

High-resolution CT of the chest can reveal intrathoracic obstruction of a large airway but would not help to identify vocal-cord dysfunction. In addition, intrathoracic obstruction would not manifest with episodic symptoms and complete resolution of airway obstruction between episodes.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a history of persistent asthma is hospitalized for wheezing that has been unresponsive to continuous treatment with nebulized bronchodilators administered in the emergency department.
She reports adherence to her prescribed doses of an inhaled glucocorticoid and a long-acting beta-agonist but still needs to use a short-acting beta-agonist rescue inhaler four or five times weekly. Her symptoms are sometimes exacerbated by exercise, but she reports no nocturnal awakenings related to shortness of breath. During the past year, she has required systemic glucocorticoids three times for presumed asthma exacerbations and was intubated once; the intubation led to immediate improvement.
Currently, she is afebrile, her heart rate is 84 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. She is mildly tachypneic with a peripheral oxygen saturation of 95% while breathing ambient air. Otoscopic examination of her ears and visual inspection of the oral cavity does not reveal any abnormalities. Her lung examination identifies a monophonic, inspiratory stridor (audible without a stethoscope) and diminished air movement throughout her lungs.
A chest radiograph shows normal lung expansion with no opacities.
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paradoxical vocal-cord motion, also known as vocal-cord dysfunction, is a relatively common condition that is often misdiagnosed as asthma. Like asthma, paradoxical vocal-cord motion is exacerbated by exercise and leads to symptoms of breathlessness with noisy breathing. Patients with this diagnosis often remain symptomatic despite adherence to evidence-based asthma therapy, and their symptoms are often exacerbated by stress.

The key physical finding in vocal-cord dysfunction is a monophonic inspiratory stridor and the absence of expiratory wheezes that are characteristic of reactive airway disease. When a patient with vocal-cord dysfunction is intubated for respiratory distress, normal airway pressures are seen, and the physical examination findings resolve immediately upon placement of the endotracheal tube through the vocal cords. In contrast, in an asthma exacerbation, there is evidence of airway obstruction (based on ventilatory parameters) and physical examination findings that take time to improve.

A diagnosis of paradoxical vocal-cord motion can be confirmed by fiberoptic laryngoscopy of the vocal cords with provocation demonstrating paradoxical adduction of the vocal cords during inspiration.

Patients with paradoxical vocal-cord motion are typically treated with speech therapy and reassurance, but continuous positive airway pressure and heliox inhalation may be used in severe acute cases.

Key learning point: A patient who has wheezing that is exacerbated by exercise, who remains symptomatic despite adherence to evidence-based asthma therapy, and who has monophonic inspiratory stridor is most likely to have a diagnosis of paradoxical vocal-cord motion.

B) INCORRECT:

Respiratory syncytial virus or Mycoplasma infection would manifest with diffuse expiratory wheezing and would not cause recurrent symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Respiratory syncytial virus or Mycoplasma infection would manifest with diffuse expiratory wheezing and would not cause recurrent symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a cause of persistent wheezing in a patient with asthma, but affected patients do not have monophonic inspiratory stridor and instead have opacities or central bronchiectasis on chest imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

A bronchial mass could cause monophonic wheezing, but it would be expiratory because intrathoracic airways become smaller and wheezing more pronounced on expiration. The symptoms also persist after intubation.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old competitive runner reports that she is having difficulty breathing when she runs a mile-long event for her college track team. During the race, she has more trouble moving air with inspiration than with expiration. Premedicating with albuterol 10 minutes before running provides little relief.
Her physical examination is normal, and her inhaler technique is observed to be excellent.
A chest radiograph is normal. On postexercise spirometry testing, all of her expiratory values are over 100% of predicted. The shape of the expiratory limb of the flow-volume loop is normal; however, the inspiratory loop is flat, and her inspiratory flow rates are decreased.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adenoid hyperplasia can cause inspiratory symptoms but would not cause extrathoracic airflow obstruction on spirometry.

B) CORRECT:

This case demonstrates many classic features of vocal-cord dysfunction — the problem is occurring in a highly competitive female athlete, the patient has more difficulty with inspiration than with expiration, and premedication with albuterol is not effective. When the patient is symptomatic, the inspiratory limb of the flow-volume loop is flat, signifying extrathoracic airflow obstruction; in contrast, when the patient is asymptomatic, spirometry would appear normal. The gold standard for diagnosing vocal-cord dysfunction is laryngoscopy, which demonstrates paradoxical vocal-cord motion during spontaneous or induced symptoms; the vocal cords adduct anteriorly either during inspiration or throughout the respiratory cycle, leaving an open posterior glottic chink.

Key learning point: The diagnosis that should be considered for a patient with exertional dyspnea whose postexercise spirometry results show an abnormal inspiratory limb of the flow-volume loop is vocal-cord dysfunction. Treatment involves relaxation exercises for the upper airway.

C) INCORRECT:

Tracheomalacia can alter the appearance of the flow-volume loop, but the expiratory (not inspiratory) limb would be flattened, reflecting the intrathoracic etiology of obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease has been associated with cough, laryngitis, and asthma, but it would not manifest with dyspnea and inspiratory abnormalities.

E) INCORRECT:

Exercise-induced bronchospasm can usually be prevented by premedicating with albuterol. Spirometry would look normal if the patient was currently asymptomatic, or it would demonstrate expiratory coving (or concavity) with a reduced FEV1 /FVC ratio.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old nonbinary person reports difficulty breathing when they play soccer with friends on the weekends. Their symptoms — which vary and include shortness of breath, wheezing, and cough — usually surface 10 to 15 minutes after the start of exercise and resolve within 30 minutes after the exercise is over. The patient does not experience symptoms at rest or at any other time during the day or night. They have no history of asthma or allergies.
Their lungs are clear to auscultation, with no wheezing, crackles, or accessory muscle use.
Pulmonary function testing after exercise reveals a 16% drop in FEV1, with a spontaneous return to baseline 30 minutes later.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The symptoms of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, which are variable and nonspecific, include chest tightness, shortness of breath, cough, and wheeze. Symptoms typically occur within 10 to 15 minutes of the individual beginning vigorous exercise or within 30 minutes of the individual stopping activity; the symptoms tend to last for 30 to 90 minutes and resolve spontaneously. Specific environments, such as ice rinks or swimming pools, can also exacerbate symptoms. A diagnosis of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction is confirmed when a patient's FEV1 decreases by more than 10% after an exercise challenge.

The most recent guidelines from the Global Initiative on Asthma (GINA) recommend use of an inhaled glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler, instead of a short-acting beta2-agonist (SABA), 15 minutes before the start of exercise. SABA-only treatment has been associated with an increased risk of exacerbations and lower lung function. It also increases allergic responses and airway inflammation and reduces bronchodilator response to SABA therapy when it is needed.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial medication for a young adult who has intermittent exercise-induced bronchoconstriction during recreational sports and no symptoms at any other time of the day is inhaled glucocorticoid-formoterol before exercise.

B) INCORRECT:

The most recent guidelines from the Global Initiative on Asthma (GINA) recommend use of an inhaled glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler, instead of a short-acting beta2-agonist (SABA), 15 minutes before the start of exercise. SABA-only treatment has been associated with an increased risk of exacerbations and lower lung function. It also increases allergic responses and airway inflammation and reduces bronchodilator response to SABA therapy when it is needed.

C) INCORRECT:

Leukotriene-receptor antagonists, such as montelukast, have a longer duration of action than short-acting agents and inhaled glucocorticoids, but they are not as effective.

D) INCORRECT:

A maintenance medication for asthma, such as an inhaled glucocorticoid, should be added if the patient exercises daily.

E) INCORRECT:

A daily long-acting beta2-agonist (LABA) can be initiated if symptoms occur on most days or wake the patient at least once a week.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman presents for an office visit. She has seasonal allergies but no other chronic medical conditions. She plays on her college volleyball team and reports that 10 to 15 minutes into each practice, she experiences “coughing fits” characterized by chest tightness and shortness of breath. She practices with her team 5 days a week, and the practices can last up to 3 hours each, especially during volleyball season.
Her physical examination is unremarkable.
In addition to encouraging the patient to continue exercising, what is the most appropriate next step in addressing her symptoms?

choices.text: Prescribe a daily low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid and an as-needed inhaled short-acting beta2-agonist
Prescribe an inhaled short-acting beta2-agonist, to be used 15 minutes before exercise
Prescribe an inhaled short-acting beta2-agonist, to be used immediately after exercise
Prescribe an antihistamine, to be used daily
Prescribe an oral glucocorticoid, to be used on days when strenuous exercise will occur

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB) is a narrowing of the lower airways that occurs during or immediately after strenuous exercise. The diagnosis should be suspected when a patient reports increased coughing, wheezing, or phlegm production in the context of physical activity. EIB is believed to stem from hyperpnea during exercise, which dries the airways and requires greater volumes of air to be humidified. The resulting water loss increases the osmolality of the airway surfaces, triggering a release of inflammatory mediators from mast cells, leading to bronchospasm. EIB is often associated with underlying asthma, but it also may occur on its own, as in this patient.

Use of a short-acting beta2-agonist before (not after) exercise has historically been the mainstay of therapy for EIB. However, evidence suggests that regular use of beta2-agonists without concurrent use of an inhaled glucocorticoid can increase airway responsiveness to bronchoconstrictor stimuli. Thus, current guidelines now recommend using a combination budesonide-formoterol inhaler before exercise to minimize symptoms, especially in those with mild asthma. This would be a reasonable option in this patient, but because she is a collegiate athlete who is exercising most days of the week, another reasonable option would be daily use of an inhaled glucocorticoid, with a short-acting beta2-agonist to be used as needed.

Key learning point: Patients with exercise-induced bronchoconstriction should use a combination budesonide-formoterol inhaler before exercise to minimize symptoms. For those who are competitive athletes and thus exercising most days of the week, another reasonable option would be daily use of an inhaled glucocorticoid, with a short-acting beta2-agonist to be used as needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Use of a short-acting beta2-agonist before (not after) exercise has historically been the mainstay of therapy for EIB. However, evidence suggests that regular use of beta2-agonists without concurrent use of an inhaled glucocorticoid can increase airway responsiveness to bronchoconstrictor stimuli. Thus, current guidelines now recommend using a combination budesonide-formoterol inhaler before exercise to minimize symptoms, especially in those with mild asthma. This would be a reasonable option in this patient, but because she is a collegiate athlete who is exercising most days of the week, another reasonable option would be daily use of an inhaled glucocorticoid, with a short-acting beta2-agonist to be used as needed.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of a short-acting beta2-agonist before (not after) exercise has historically been the mainstay of therapy for EIB. However, evidence suggests that regular use of beta2-agonists without concurrent use of an inhaled glucocorticoid can increase airway responsiveness to bronchoconstrictor stimuli. Thus, current guidelines now recommend using a combination budesonide-formoterol inhaler before exercise to minimize symptoms, especially in those with mild asthma. This would be a reasonable option in this patient, but because she is a collegiate athlete who is exercising most days of the week, another reasonable option would be daily use of an inhaled glucocorticoid, with a short-acting beta2-agonist to be used as needed.

D) INCORRECT:

Exercise-induced anaphylaxis may share features of EIB but would affect more than one organ system. Epinephrine and histamine blockade would be the indicated treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Although oral glucocorticoids are important in treating asthma exacerbations, they are not recommended as preventive therapy for EIB. Moreover, long-term oral glucocorticoid use has many adverse effects. Prescribing medications in athletes requires consideration of doping regulations. Oral and intravenous glucocorticoids would require a therapeutic-use exception from the World Anti-Doping Agency.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl reports difficulty breathing during her soccer matches. Her symptoms vary and include shortness of breath, wheezing, and cough. The symptoms usually surface within 10 to 15 minutes after she starts to exercise and resolve within 30 minutes after she stops. She does not experience symptoms at rest or at any other time during the day or night. She has no history of asthma or allergies.
Her lungs are clear to auscultation, with no wheezing, rales, or accessory muscle use.
Pulmonary function testing after exercise reveals a 16% drop in FEV1, with a spontaneous return to baseline 30 minutes later.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A short-acting inhaled anticholinergic agent, such as ipratropium, may be added if symptoms persist after a trial of a short-acting beta2-agonist.

B) INCORRECT:

A combination budesonide-formoterol inhaler before exercise is also a reasonable initial management option, but a daily long-acting beta2-agonist alone would not be appropriate

C) INCORRECT:

Leukotriene-receptor antagonists, such as montelukast, have a longer duration of action than short-acting agents and inhaled glucocorticoids, but they are not as effective.

D) INCORRECT:

A controller agent, such as an inhaled glucocorticoid, should be added if a short-acting agent is needed daily or more frequently.

E) CORRECT:

Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction/bronchospasm has an estimated prevalence of 10% among school-age children, but the exact figure is unknown because of inconsistent diagnosis and varying definitions.

The symptoms of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, which are variable and nonspecific, include chest tightness, shortness of breath, cough, or wheeze. Symptoms typically occur within 10 to 15 minutes of the individual beginning vigorous exercise or within 30 minutes of the individual stopping activity; the symptoms tend to last for 30 to 90 minutes and resolve spontaneously. Specific environments, such as ice rinks or swimming pools, can also exacerbate symptoms. A diagnosis of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction is confirmed when a patient's FEV1 decreases by more than 10% after an exercise challenge.

Initial therapeutic management of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction should begin with a short-acting beta2-agonist administered 15 minutes before the start of activity. A combination budesonide-formoterol inhaler before exercise is also a reasonable initial management option, but a daily long-acting beta2-agonist alone would not be appropriate

A short-acting inhaled anticholinergic agent, such as ipratropium, may be added if symptoms persist after a trial of a short-acting beta2-agonist. A controller agent, such as an inhaled glucocorticoid, should be added if a short-acting agent is needed daily or more frequently.

Leukotriene-receptor antagonists, such as montelukast, have a longer duration of action than short-acting agents and inhaled glucocorticoids, but they are not as effective.

Antihistamines are recommended only for patients who suffer from exercise-induced bronchoconstriction and allergies and whose symptoms are not controlled by a short-acting beta2-agonist alone.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial medication for a 16-year-old girl with intermittent exercise-induced bronchoconstriction and no symptoms at any other time of the day is a short-acting beta2-agonist.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is having difficulty when running on the playground. His parents describe a dry cough and say that he reports chest discomfort when he is physically active. In addition, he seems to get tired early during exercise and cannot keep up with his friends. No fever, rhinorrhea, diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea has been associated with these episodes.
The patient’s current vital signs are normal. He appears well, with no evidence of increased work of breathing. His first and second heart sounds are normal with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. His peripheral pulses are also normal. Both lungs are clear to auscultation with good air movement. His abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended with no hepatosplenomegaly.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Trial of an albuterol inhaler with spacer before exercise
Empiric treatment with a histamine-2-receptor antagonist

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has symptoms typical of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, including a dry cough and difficulty breathing with exercise. The differential diagnosis for dyspnea on exertion includes cardiac conditions, interstitial lung disease, anemia, and many other possible causes. Given that this patient is otherwise well and had a normal physical examination, exercise-induced bronchoconstriction is the most likely diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial therapy for a child with features of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction is pre-exercise bronchodilators.

B) INCORRECT:

Pre- and post-exercise spirometry is the gold standard for diagnosing exercise-induced bronchoconstriction in older children. At age 4, this child is too young to produce reliable spirometry results. Even in older children, spirometry is not always necessary if the child’s history and physical examination are completely consistent with exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. Spirometry would be used if such a child did not respond to empiric treatment with a bronchodilator or if there were features of another pulmonary disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Chest radiographs are unnecessary given the absence of fevers or focal lung findings makes community-acquired pneumonia unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Treatment with a histamine-2-receptor antagonist is not warranted. Although a cough can result from gastroesophageal reflux, this patient’s dyspnea on exertion and the lack of a reported association between his cough and eating are not consistent with that diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhaled glucocorticoids are appropriate as a later step in the management of asthma that is persistent.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with a history of exercise-induced asthma presents to clinic. Her current regimen consists of a daily low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid and a short-acting beta-agonist that she takes before exercise.
During the past few months, she has noted difficulty playing soccer. She has had no trouble during practice but reports shortness of breath and wheezing 2 to 3 minutes into games. Albuterol does not seem to prevent these symptoms. She notes that she often needs to sit down and rest and that the symptoms may last for several minutes but can also linger for up to an hour. She has had no cough, history of gastroesophageal reflux disease, history of recent illness, or symptoms outside of soccer. A trial of ipratropium before exercise has not led to any improvement.
She is afebrile, her heart rate is 88 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100% while she is breathing ambient air. Her examination is unremarkable. Her voice is clear without breathiness or hoarseness. She has no stridor at rest.
A spirometry tracing is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate a course of systemic glucocorticoids
Add a long-acting beta-agonist to her daily regimen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Like asthma, VCD is episodic, making it difficult to recreate the exact scenario leading to the inappropriate adduction of the vocal cords. As a result, pulmonary function test results will often be normal, and direct laryngoscopy (although it could reveal the diagnosis) is not sufficiently sensitive. Bronchoprovocation testing (for example, with methacholine) is not necessary in patients with suspected VCD.

B) INCORRECT:

Like asthma, VCD is episodic, making it difficult to recreate the exact scenario leading to the inappropriate adduction of the vocal cords. As a result, pulmonary function test results will often be normal, and direct laryngoscopy (although it could reveal the diagnosis) is not sufficiently sensitive. Bronchoprovocation testing (for example, with methacholine) is not necessary in patients with suspected VCD.

C) INCORRECT:

VCD can occur in patients with asthma but should be treated differently. Adding a long-acting beta-agonist to this patient’s regimen or initiating systemic glucocorticoids is therefore not appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

This patient likely has exercise-induced vocal-cord dysfunction (VCD), a disorder that is often mischaracterized as exercise-induced asthma.

VCD (also called paradoxical vocal fold motion, episodic paroxysmal laryngospasm, factitious asthma, and psychogenic stridor, among other names) is caused by inappropriate vocal-cord adduction during inspiration, producing partial airway obstruction. The exact mechanism is unclear but is thought to be mediated via cholinergic pathways. For this reason, some patients will respond favorably to ipratropium given before exercise.

Anxiety and stress may contribute to exercise-induced VCD. Thus, patients may be more likely to experience symptoms during games, when the pressure is greater, than during practices. Patients may also experience symptoms only during certain sports and then are completely asymptomatic with other forms of exercise.

Distinguishing between exercise-induced VCD and asthma can be difficult but hinges on the specific symptoms and the timing of onset relative to exercise. Cough, wheeze, chest tightness, and dyspnea are typical features of exercise-induced asthma and do not typically occur until 10 to 15 minutes into exercise. This patient’s case is more consistent with VCD: her symptoms begin 2 to 3 minutes into exercise, she is only symptomatic during games, she does not respond to albuterol, and she denies cough. Although she describes a wheeze, most patients are not able to distinguish wheeze from stridor, and the latter is what occurs in exercise-induced VCD.

Initial management of VCD may involve a trial of ipratropium given before exercise, especially if a speech pathologist trained in exercise-induced VCD is not available. In this case, the patient did not respond to such a trial, and voice therapy by a trained speech pathologist would be the most appropriate next step.

Key learning point: The symptoms of exercise-induced asthma do not typically start until 10 to 15 minutes into exercise and often respond to inhaled therapies taken before or during exacerbations. In contrast, the symptoms associated with exercise-induced vocal-cord dysfunction usually occur within 2 to 3 minutes after onset of exercise and do not respond acutely to inhaled beta-agonists.

E) INCORRECT:

VCD can occur in patients with asthma but should be treated differently. Adding a long-acting beta-agonist to this patient’s regimen or initiating systemic glucocorticoids is therefore not appropriate.

A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest could reveal a pulmonary disease underlying this patient's respiratory symptoms. However, in this patient with symptoms suggestive of exercise-induced asthma, CT would be unlikely to reveal an underlying condition. In addition, the substantial amount of radiation should especially be avoided in this teenage girl.

B) CORRECT:

Exercise-induced asthma presents with symptoms of bronchoconstriction (e.g., shortness of breath, chest tightness) that typically peaks 10–15 minutes after beginning exercise. Exercise-induced asthma is treated with short-acting β2-agonists (e.g., albuterol) taken shortly (5–20 minutes) before exercise. Due to the risk of tachyphylaxis, β2-agonists should preferentially only be used before the most strenuous exercise sessions. Additional treatment options include avoiding exercise in cold weather (or using a mask to warm inhaled air) and avoiding triggers (allergic or environmental).

C) INCORRECT:

Prednisone therapy would not be the first-line therapy in exercise-induced asthma in a patient who has not tried other methods. Prednisone would generally be indicated if the patient had severe underlying asthma with an acute exacerbation that is not relieved by inhaled bronchodilators.

D) INCORRECT:

Although improved physical conditioning can improve minute ventilation and help improve the symptoms of exercise-induced asthma, this patient should initially be offered alternative management to help with her underlying disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography can be useful in young patients who present with symptoms suggestive of congestive heart failure (peripheral edema, crackles), hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (systolic murmur), or other valvular abnormalities. Cardiac involvement is unlikely in this patient whose physical examination showed no abnormalities and who has no symptoms at rest.
questions.hint: This adolescent girl has features of bronchoconstriction such as shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and chest tightness only while playing sports. Her spirometry findings are normal. These findings suggest exercise-induced asthma.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old high school athlete presents with repeated episodes of chest tightness and coughing during intense running events. These episodes begin within a few minutes of starting activity. He denies any baseline respiratory difficulties. He takes no regular medications. His mother had similar complaints as a teenager. Examination at rest is normal.
Which of the following measures is most likely to prevent his symptoms during exercise?

choices.text: Take a long-acting beta-agonist every morning
Inhale a short-acting beta-agonist prior to exercise
Use a moderate-dose inhaled corticosteroid daily
Start a daily leukotriene receptor antagonist

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-acting beta-agonists (LABAs) are a suitable option for exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. However, these should only be taken before exercise and a maximum of 3 times/week, not daily. Monotherapy with daily LABA has been associated with an increased risk of asthma exacerbations.

B) CORRECT:

Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction manifests with symptoms like chest tightness and coughing due to airway cooling and drying during intense activity. This triggers mast cell mediator release, leading to bronchial smooth muscle contraction. Inhaled short-acting beta-agonists, such as albuterol, provide bronchodilation by activating beta2-adrenergic receptors, counteracting this constriction. Administering a short-acting beta-agonist before exercise effectively prevents symptoms by maintaining airway patency during exertion.

Key learning point: For exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, a short-acting beta-agonist like salbutamol is recommended for use before exercise to prevent symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhaled corticosteroids are effective for chronic inflammatory airway conditions, such as persistent asthma, but are not indicated for isolated exercise-induced symptoms. This patient experiences symptoms only during exercise, suggesting transient airway reactivity rather than chronic inflammation. Pre-exercise short-acting beta-agonists are more appropriate for preventing exercise-induced bronchospasm.

D) INCORRECT:

Leukotriene receptor antagonists reduce airway inflammation and bronchoconstriction but are primarily used in persistent asthma. They do not provide the rapid bronchodilation needed for exercise-induced symptoms. This patient has symptoms only during exercise, making on-demand therapy with short-acting beta-agonists more suitable.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old high school athlete presents to the Emergency Department with recurrent episodes of difficulty breathing and a high-pitched noise during inspiration. These episodes often occur during intense workouts and occasionally at rest, resolving suddenly each time. She has tried a short-acting inhaler with minimal relief. Between episodes, her chest examination is normal, and chest radiographs are normal (see report).
Spirometry: isolated inspiratory flow limitation
Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vocal cord dysfunction involves paradoxical adduction of the vocal cords during inspiration, causing transient extrathoracic airway obstruction and a high-pitched inspiratory noise. It is common in young athletes, especially females, and presents with episodic breathing difficulty during exercise or at rest. The normal chest examination and imaging between episodes, along with spirometry showing isolated inspiratory flow limitation, support this diagnosis. These clinical and spirometric patterns are crucial for understanding and confirming vocal cord dysfunction.

Key learning point: Vocal cord dysfunction syndrome can mimic asthma with symptoms of dyspnea and wheezing, but it is characterized by inspiratory wheeze and does not respond to bronchodilators, often resolving suddenly.

B) INCORRECT:

Asthma typically involves lower airway bronchoconstriction, expiratory wheezing, and improvement with bronchodilators. The high-pitched inspiratory noise and isolated inspiratory abnormality on spirometry suggest an upper airway issue, not the lower airway obstruction seen in asthma. The lack of response to the inhaler further argues against asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

Exercise-induced bronchospasm causes expiratory wheezing during or after exertion and responds to bronchodilators. The high-pitched inspiratory noise and isolated inspiratory abnormality on spirometry are uncharacteristic for this condition, which primarily affects the expiratory phase. Minimal response to inhaler therapy also contradicts this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Panic disorder can cause dyspnea and a sense of choking, but it is usually accompanied by palpitations, chest discomfort, and anxiety. The high-pitched inspiratory noise and isolated inspiratory abnormality on spirometry suggest a mechanical upper airway issue, not a psychogenic cause. Symptoms triggered by physical activity further differentiate it from panic disorder.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old college athlete presents with severe shortness of breath and throat tightness during intense workouts. She has a history of mild intermittent asthma and uses a short-acting β2-agonist when symptoms occur, but her inhaler provides no relief lately. She denies symptoms at rest or overnight. Physical examination is normal at rest. She notes that her symptoms usually begin within a few minutes of starting exercise and are sometimes accompanied by a harsh inspiratory noise (see report).
Spirometry: Normal at rest with FEV1 3.5 L (95% of predicted) and no significant change post-bronchodilator
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Refer for otolaryngology evaluation with direct laryngoscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The methacholine challenge test detects airway hyperresponsiveness in suspected asthma. This patient's symptoms are exercise-induced, with normal spirometry and no bronchodilator response, suggesting a condition like vocal cord dysfunction. Methacholine testing does not reproduce transient changes seen in exercise-induced conditions.

B) INCORRECT:

Chest CT scans evaluate fixed structural abnormalities or parenchymal lung diseases. This patient's exercise-induced symptoms and normal resting spirometry suggest a dynamic upper airway issue, not a structural or parenchymal problem. A CT scan at rest would not capture transient changes occurring during exertion.

C) CORRECT:

Exercise-induced laryngeal obstruction (EILO) manifests in young athletes with symptoms like severe shortness of breath, throat tightness, and a harsh inspiratory noise during exercise. Normal spirometry at rest and no bronchodilator response differentiate EILO from asthma. Direct laryngoscopy during exercise or symptom provocation is crucial for diagnosing EILO, as it reveals transient laryngeal obstruction, such as paradoxical vocal cord motion. This evaluation is essential for appropriate management by otolaryngology specialists.

Key learning point: In patients with exercise-induced respiratory symptoms not relieved by asthma treatment, consider vocal cord dysfunction and refer for otolaryngology evaluation for direct visualization of the vocal cords.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing inhaled corticosteroids targets chronic airway inflammation in persistent asthma. This patient has normal resting spirometry and no bronchodilator response, indicating that her symptoms are not due to active airway inflammation. The harsh inspiratory noise suggests extrathoracic airflow obstruction, not bronchoconstriction, making corticosteroid escalation inappropriate.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male runner presents with episodes of wheezing, shortness of breath, and coughing that begin 5 minutes into his daily sprints and resolve shortly after stopping. He has no baseline respiratory symptoms and takes no medications. Physical examination is normal. He seeks advice on controlling these symptoms to continue training effectively.
Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention for his exercise-related respiratory episodes?

choices.text: Inhaled short-acting β₂ agonist before exercise

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Exercise-induced bronchospasm manifests as transient airway narrowing due to thermal and osmotic changes during physical activity. Inhaled short-acting β₂ agonists, such as salbutamol, administered 10–15 minutes before exercise, activate β₂ receptors, increasing intracellular cyclic AMP and causing bronchodilation. This provides effective prophylaxis against exercise-induced airway narrowing without affecting baseline respiratory function, making it ideal for individuals with exercise-related bronchospasm.

Key learning point: Inhaled salbutamol, a short-acting beta-agonist, is the first-line treatment for acute relief of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhaled anticholinergic agents block muscarinic receptors to reduce bronchoconstriction but are less effective for exercise-induced bronchospasm, which involves transient airway cooling and osmotic changes. β₂-agonists provide more rapid and effective prevention.

C) INCORRECT:

Montelukast, a leukotriene receptor antagonist, requires continuous use for efficacy, suitable for persistent symptoms or chronic inflammation. This patient has isolated exercise-induced episodes, needing rapid, short-term intervention rather than prolonged treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Daily low-dose inhaled corticosteroids reduce chronic airway inflammation in persistent asthma. This patient has isolated exercise-induced symptoms without baseline inflammation, making corticosteroids inappropriate. They do not provide rapid bronchodilation needed for acute exercise-related bronchospasm.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, who is a competitive swimmer, presents with a 6-week history of dyspnea and cough during training sessions. Symptoms begin 5–10 minutes into practice and worsen despite stopping activity, lasting up to 45 minutes. She has no known medical history or allergies. Physical examination and chest x-ray are normal. She underwent spirometry testing yesterday that shows FEV1 of 85% predicted with no improvement after bronchodilator administration. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Refer for outpatient exercise challenge testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Daily inhaled corticosteroids are reserved for patients with confirmed exercise-induced bronchoconstriction who have refractory symptoms or require bronchodilator therapy 4 or more times per week. Diagnostic confirmation is needed before considering daily therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Avoiding environmental triggers is part of nonpharmacological management for confirmed exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, but diagnostic confirmation should be obtained first. Additionally, recommending a different pool without confirming chlorine sensitivity is premature, especially in this case, considering the impact on a competitive athlete.

C) INCORRECT:

Pre-exercise bronchodilator therapy is appropriate for confirmed exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, but this patient requires diagnostic confirmation first. With normal spirometry and no bronchodilator response, empiric treatment is not the most appropriate initial step.

D) INCORRECT:

While cardiac causes should be considered in exercise-induced dyspnea, this patient's symptoms worsen after stopping exercise and last 45 minutes, which is more consistent with exercise-induced bronchoconstriction than cardiac pathology that typically resolves quickly with rest.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has classic symptoms of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB), normal spirometry, and no change with a bronchodilator. According to diagnostic guidelines, if spirometry is normal but EIB is still suspected, bronchial provocation testing (e.g., exercise challenge) is indicated to confirm the diagnosis before initiating treatment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who is a competitive swimmer, presents with a 6-month history of dyspnea and chest tightness during training sessions. She has a confirmed diagnosis of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. She has been using albuterol prior to swimming 4–5 times weekly with only a transient improvement in her symptoms. She has no known past medical history and has normal vital signs and physical examination. She has an important competition coming up and wants something to help her symptoms. What is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Discharge with daily inhaled corticosteroid and pulmonology follow-up
Discharge with oral corticosteroids and sports medicine referral
Discharge with montelukast and return if symptoms worsen

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient requires daily inhaled corticosteroids as she is currently using beta-agonists 4–5 times weekly, suggesting refractory exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. Use of bronchodilators more than 4 times a week suggests poorly controlled symptoms and risks the development of tachyphylaxis.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids are not indicated for exercise-induced bronchoconstriction management. Sports medicine referral is inappropriate because this patient's presentation requires pulmonology expertise for airway management rather than exercise physiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Exercise stress testing is not indicated. This patient has a confirmed diagnosis of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction and requires escalation of her pharmacological treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

While montelukast can be used for refractory exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, this patient would benefit from specialist evaluation rather than symptomatic management alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Increasing albuterol frequency is inappropriate because patients should not use inhaled beta-agonists more than 3 times per week due to the risk of tachyphylaxis. This patient already exceeds the threshold requiring daily therapy.
